awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Searching for Dark Matter Subhalos in Distant Strong Gravitational Lenses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to transform the NSF facility ALMA, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, into a powerful probe of the fundamental physics of dark matter and the astrophysics of galaxy formation, using an effect known as gravitational lensing first predicted by Einstein over a century ago.  The main goal of the project is to quantify the properties of dark matter, the mysterious component of our Universe whose gravity binds galaxies together but which has eluded detection in collider experiments at our most advanced accelerators.  Dark matter represents the most compelling evidence for new physics beyond the Standard Model of fundamental physics developed over 40 years ago and has therefore been the subject of intensive study, both theoretical and experimental, for many decades.  Research supported by this grant will be incorporated into a program for integrating astronomy into 5th grade classrooms in Illinois, and undergraduates from underrepresented groups will participate in research activities under this project at Stanford.

The research program involves a suite of theoretical, numerical, and observational research to lay the groundwork needed to translate ALMA observations of lensed dusty galaxies into constraints on the microphysical properties of dark matter.  ALMA observations of gravitationally lensed galaxies will be used to search for substructure in the mass distributions of the lensing objects.  Given the scale of ALMA data sets and the complexity of the lens modeling required to detect extremely subtle effects of low-mass substructure, this analysis will be performed on petascale computing facilities like NSF's Blue Waters using a novel analysis pipeline developed by the investigating team.  Numerical simulations will be used to quantify the abundance of substructure expected in a variety of dark matter models that explore different physical characteristics of dark matter including various self-interactions, temperatures, and Compton wavelengths, using novel simulation software written by the investigating team.  In addition, stacked optical/IR observations of detected dark matter subhalos will provide the most stringent bounds to date on the mean stellar mass - halo mass relation in the smallest galaxies, a crucial input for all models of galaxy formation.

por.por_cntn:
This work made a series of advances in strong lensing modeling and inference, with applications to data from the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) and the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).

Intellectual merit: This work developed new techniques for statistical inference from both HST and interferometric strong lensing data to learn about the properties of dark matter structure.  This includied new techniques for determining uncertainties in parameter estimation and new methods to combine convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks to estimate the parameters of strong gravitational lenses from observations. These techniques provided more than six orders of magnitude increase in analysis speed while using about eight orders of magnitude less computational resources compared to maximum-likelihood lens modeling in the UV-plane of interferometric data. This work also enabled the realistic rendering of low mass dark matter halos, including the scatter in the mass--concentration relation, spatial distribution, line-of-sight halo population, and parameterized forms of the impact of disruption physics. These advances enabled the combination of Milky Way satellite abundances with strong lensing signatures to provide world-leading constraints on warm dark matter and other dark matter models that suppress the formation of cosmic structure.  The work led to a new pipeline for simulation-based inferrence of strong gravitational lenses that will be used to analyze data from the Hubble Space Telescope.

Broader Impacts:This work trained postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students in leading methods at the interface of astronomy and machine learning, with balanced gender representation at all levels of the team. Our work on using Bayesian Neural Nets to determine uncertainties in parameter estimation has had an impact well beyond the strong lensing community to several areas inside and outside astrophysics. The work was accompanied with open-source software that generates the large mock training sets, including the paltas,  baobab and deeplenstronomy codes and the analysis pipelines ovajero and h0rton. These software packages enabled a number of researchers interested in ML/AI to access strong lensing simulations, and provided people in astrophysics with end-to-end examples of how ML can be applied in Bayesian inference. Wechsler played a leading role in initiating programs to bring underrepresented students into research at Stanford and SLAC, including through the Cal-Bridge Summer Program and the Leadership Alliance SR-EIP Program, and through modifying practices at Stanford to be more welcoming for students with diverse identities to engage in early research. This played a role in attracting undergraduate research students to several programs across physics and astronomy at Stanford. This work also resulted in a set of interactive lecture notes on strong gravitational lensing that have been widely used.
